Award.AwardTitle: Enhancing Academic Achievement and Career Preparation for Scholars in Computer Science, Mathematics, and Engineering

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The five-year S-STEM program at Shepherd University provides support for 30 students majoring in Computer Sciences, Mathematics and Engineering (CME) and has four objectives: (1) increase enrollment of first-year and transfer students in CME, (2) increase retention of S-STEM scholars, (3) increase the four-year graduation rate of S-STEM scholars, and (4) increase the proportion of graduating S-STEM scholars who continue graduate studies or find employment in their field within six months of graduation.

Intellectual merit

The program provides financial, academic, social, and career support to a diverse cohort of students, particularly first generation (a large percentage of the student body), female, and transfer students, and assesses the effect of these supports on their retention and graduation rates. Student learning, engagement, and career preparation are enhanced through tutoring, faculty and peer mentoring, learning communities, CME student clubs, close interaction with industry and government agencies, and research, internship, and networking opportunities. The focus on first generation, transfer, and female students--the latter highly underrepresented in CME fields--demonstrates which recruitment and support activities are most effective at encouraging these populations to continue to baccalaureate-level studies.

Broader impacts

The program strengthens and applies student support systems to the educational success of a diverse community of CME scholars. In particular, it eliminates barriers and seeks to improve retention of first generation, transfer, and female students in STEM fields. Entering students from small towns and rural areas and transfer students from community colleges are supported and encouraged to complete their education at least to the baccalaureate level. The program strengthens student education, undergraduate research, and career counseling infrastructure; enhances Shepherd's regional alliance with business, industry, and government agencies; and improves connections with local high schools and community colleges.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Shepherd University S-STEM project provided financial, academic, social, and career support to a diverse cohort of first-generation college students, minority students, and students who come from low-income families. The program supported 57 students during 2013 and 2019. The overall goal of the scholarship program was to increase the number of STEM graduates by providing financial, academic, and social supports, thereby enabling qualified students to overcome some of the barriers that prevent them from meeting their educational goals.

     The grant improved many aspects of student data including enrollment, retention and graduation rates for the Computer Science, Mathematics and Engineering Department (CME). The number of CME majors has increased 10.6% despite a 12.9% enrollment drop for SU during fall 2013 and fall 2018. In addition, the percentages of minorities, first-time-in-college students, annual degrees for minorities and females, and the average number of annual degrees have all increased. A steadily increasing pattern of the 1-year retention rate, 4-year graduation rate and number of graduated CME students every year throughout the grant period has been observed during the funding period of this project.

      The focus on transfer students demonstrates that the recruitment and support activities were most effective in encouraging this population to continue to baccalaureate-level studies as the transfer students have been  the most successful group among S-STEM scholars: 13 out of 18 (72%) S-STEM transfer students graduated with a Bachelor of Science (B.S.) degree with 92% (12 out of 13) working or continuing to the graduate studies within 6-month after graduation, 6% left program due to no financial need, 3 (17%) left the program due to non-financial reasons, the rest one (6%) is continuing.

       Student learning and engagement for all participants were enhanced through tutoring, faculty mentoring, CME student clubs, learning communities, peer support groups, and research and internship opportunities. CME faculty members have strong ties to local businesses, industry, and government agencies, and local employers actively participated through employment seminars and internship positions. Shepherd provided strong opportunities for student/faculty interactions, including participation in CME-oriented events and activities (e.g., IEEE chapter events, robotics and programming clubs and competitions, and math competitions) and opportunities for students to participate in research mentored by faculty. Students benefit from Shepherd?s comprehensive technology labs and from research opportunities, internships, networking opportunities, and exposure to industry. Fifteen out of 17 (88%) graduated students either found jobs or continued to graduate studies in a STEM field within 6 months after graduation. Twelve out of these 15 students (80%) had undergraduate research and/or internship experience through local industry or government, the NASA fellowship, SOARS summer undergraduate research experience, NIST summer internship, WV-INBRE PUI Research Awards, etc.

     The project strengthened student support systems for the educational success of a diverse community of CME scholars. In particular, the program improved education and career development opportunities for first generation in college, transfer, and female students in STEM fields by the supportive environment, learning communities, and strong student/faculty interactions available at Shepherd. The program supported 23 first generation students (40%), 18 transfer students (31.6%), 10 female students (17.5%), 9 minorities (15.8%) and 3 students with disabilities (5.3%). The project strengthened CME?s student education, undergraduate research, and career counseling infrastructure; enhances Shepherd?s regional alliance with business, industry, and government agencies; and improves connections with local high schools and community colleges. Shepherd worked closely with 6 partner community colleges in recruitment and articulation agreements. The program sponsored 35 S-STEM seminars/workshops, 3 fieldtrips, 23 undergraduate conference presentations, and 3 students for programming competitions. Project results were disseminated through 7 conference presentations, SU CME S-STEM website, CME group in social media, and local events such as Shepherd Open house, and summer registration and advising sections.
